articles.headline: Talks for Lucent May Signal End for 90's Symbol
articles.snippet: Lucent Technologies, the phone equipment maker that became a symbol of last decade's boom-and-bust cycle in telecommunications, is in negotiations to be acquired by Alcatel of France for about $12.6 billion, people close to the discussions said la...
articles.abstract: Lucent Technologies, the phone equipment maker that became a symbol of last decade's boom-and-bust cycle in telecommunications, is in negotiations to be acquired by Alcatel of France for about $12.6 billion, people close to the discussions said last night.      The two companies confirmed the talks last night in a statement, saying they were ''engaged in discussions about a potential merger of equals.''
articles.lead_paragraph: Lucent Technologies, the phone equipment maker that became a symbol of last decade's boom-and-bust cycle in telecommunications, is in negotiations to be acquired by Alcatel of France for about $12.6 billion, people close to the discussions said last night.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Ken Belson

articles.headline: G.M. Sells Big Stake in Loan Unit
articles.snippet: General Motors sold a 78 percent stake in its commercial mortgage business, one part of its vast financing division, to an investor group on Thursday, the latest move in the struggling automaker's efforts to raise cash. The deal includes $1.5 bill...
articles.abstract: General Motors sold a 78 percent stake in its commercial mortgage business, one part of its vast financing division, to an investor group on Thursday, the latest move in the struggling automaker's efforts to raise cash. The deal includes $1.5 billion in cash and the repayment of about $7.3 billion in intercompany loans.     The sale came a day after G.M. announced a landmark deal with the United Automobile Workers union that will offer buyouts to all 113,000 of its hourly workers in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, March 23 - General Motors sold a 78 percent stake in its commercial mortgage business, one part of its vast financing division, to an investor group on Thursday, the latest move in the struggling automaker's efforts to raise cash. The deal includes $1.5 billion in cash and the repayment of about $7.3 billion in intercompany loans.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: 3 Hostages Rescued in Iraq
articles.snippet: A multinational military force rescued two Canadians and a Briton held hostage in Iraq for nearly four months by a shadowy guerrilla group. Page A8.
articles.abstract: A multinational military force rescued two Canadians and a Briton held hostage in Iraq for nearly four months by a shadowy guerrilla group. Page A8.
articles.lead_paragraph: A multinational military force rescued two Canadians and a Briton held hostage in Iraq for nearly four months by a shadowy guerrilla group. Page A8.

articles.headline: Testimony on Enron Weakened a Day Later
articles.snippet: Under questioning by defense lawyers, Enron's former treasurer backed away on Thursday from statements that Jeffrey K. Skilling had supported a controversial off-the-books transaction as a way to skirt accounting rules, and admitted to other weakn...
articles.abstract: Under questioning by defense lawyers, Enron's former treasurer backed away on Thursday from statements that Jeffrey K. Skilling had supported a controversial off-the-books transaction as a way to skirt accounting rules, and admitted to other weaknesses in his earlier testimony.     But Ben F. Glisan Jr., the last high-level manager expected to testify for the government in the criminal trial of Mr. Skilling, a former Enron chief executive, and the company's founder, Kenneth L. Lay, continued to insist that the Raptors financing vehicle he designed had no economic value. Instead, Mr. Glisan said, the Raptors was really an accounting artifice that won plaudits from Mr. Skilling and Mr. Lay for its ability to help Enron avoid reporting hundreds of millions of dollars in losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, March 23 - Under questioning by defense lawyers, Enron's former treasurer backed away on Thursday from statements that Jeffrey K. Skilling had supported a controversial off-the-books transaction as a way to skirt accounting rules, and admitted to other weaknesses in his earlier testimony.

articles.headline: A Show of Hands on Wal-Mart
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart, says the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, is a ''generous and thoughtful'' partner that has helped recover 140 missing children. Maybe so, but the liberal group Americans for Democratic Action argues that Wal-Mart is '...
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart, says the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, is a ''generous and thoughtful'' partner that has helped recover 140 missing children. Maybe so, but the liberal group Americans for Democratic Action argues that Wal-Mart is ''socially irresponsible'' for skimping on employee wages.     A dispute over a new store? Not exactly. Instead, these two groups -- and an eclectic collection of 69 more -- have signed up to testify before federal regulators deciding, of all things, whether Wal-Mart can open a bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart, says the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, is a "generous and thoughtful" partner that has helped recover 140 missing children. Maybe so, but the liberal group Americans for Democratic Action argues that Wal-Mart is "socially irresponsible" for skimping on employee wages.

articles.headline: Women Wage Key Campaigns for Democrats
articles.snippet: If the Democrats have their way, the 2006 Congressional elections will be the revenge of the mommy party.     Democratic women are running major campaigns in nearly half of the two dozen most competitive House races where their party hopes to pick...
articles.abstract: If the Democrats have their way, the 2006 Congressional elections will be the revenge of the mommy party.     Democratic women are running major campaigns in nearly half of the two dozen most competitive House races where their party hopes to pick up enough Republican seats to regain control of the House. Democratic strategists are betting that the voters' unrest and hunger for change -- reflected consistently in public opinion polls -- create the perfect conditions for their party's female candidates this year.

articles.headline: Military Lab Puts Name on a Long-Lost Airman
articles.snippet: The melting snow of the Sierra Nevada fell away from the airman inch by inch. He lay facedown, his hair thick and blond atop a crushed head.      Last October, two hikers on the Darwin Glacier in California spotted a piece of cloth, moved closer a...
articles.abstract: The melting snow of the Sierra Nevada fell away from the airman inch by inch. He lay facedown, his hair thick and blond atop a crushed head.      Last October, two hikers on the Darwin Glacier in California spotted a piece of cloth, moved closer and found him. His arms were spread as if in free fall. The parachute pack on his back read ''U.S. Army,'' and it was unopened.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONOLULU, March 23 - The melting snow of the Sierra Nevada fell away from the airman inch by inch. He lay facedown, his hair thick and blond atop a crushed head.

articles.headline: Red Cross Sifting Internal Charges Over Katrina Aid
articles.snippet: The American Red Cross, the largest recipient of donations after Hurricane Katrina, is investigating wide ranging accusations of impropriety among volunteers after the disaster.     John F. McGuire, the interim president and chief executive of the...
articles.abstract: The American Red Cross, the largest recipient of donations after Hurricane Katrina, is investigating wide ranging accusations of impropriety among volunteers after the disaster.     John F. McGuire, the interim president and chief executive of the Red Cross, and Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said some of the actions might have been criminal.

articles.headline: Evidence of Wiretaps Used in Suit
articles.snippet: A screenwriter and his lawyer talk on the phone. They are in the heat of legal battle with a big-time producer over the profits from a hit movie. The lawyer says which of their arguments he thinks are strongest and how much he thinks their opponen...
articles.abstract: A screenwriter and his lawyer talk on the phone. They are in the heat of legal battle with a big-time producer over the profits from a hit movie. The lawyer says which of their arguments he thinks are strongest and how much he thinks their opponents will agree to pay in a settlement.     Unbeknownst to both of them, Anthony Pellicano is listening in, and taking notes, court filings say.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, March 23 - A screenwriter and his lawyer talk on the phone. They are in the heat of legal battle with a big-time producer over the profits from a hit movie. The lawyer says which of their arguments he thinks are strongest and how much he thinks their opponents will agree to pay in a settlement.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Allison Hope Weiner

articles.headline: To Some, Need for Third Trial of Ex-Banker Isn't Evident
articles.snippet: What do John A. Gotti; Cendant's former chief executive, Walter A. Forbes; and Frank P. Quattrone, the former investment banker, all have in common?     As vastly different as those three cases are, they may all be threepeats, with each facing the...
articles.abstract: What do John A. Gotti; Cendant's former chief executive, Walter A. Forbes; and Frank P. Quattrone, the former investment banker, all have in common?     As vastly different as those three cases are, they may all be threepeats, with each facing the prospect of a third trial in federal court.
articles.lead_paragraph: What do John A. Gotti; Cendant's former chief executive, Walter A. Forbes; and Frank P. Quattrone, the former investment banker, all have in common?

articles.headline: Schering Gets Bid From Bayer
articles.snippet: In a bid that could help partly restore Germany's historic prominence in the pharmaceutical industry, the drug and chemical giant Bayer yesterday announced a nearly $20 billion offer for its smaller rival, Schering, topping a $17.9 billion offer b...
articles.abstract: In a bid that could help partly restore Germany's historic prominence in the pharmaceutical industry, the drug and chemical giant Bayer yesterday announced a nearly $20 billion offer for its smaller rival, Schering, topping a $17.9 billion offer by Merck of Germany.     Bayer, a 143-year-old company best known as the inventor of aspirin, said it would pay 86 euros ($103) a share in cash for Schering, which last week rebuffed an offer of 77 euros ($92) a share by Merck. Schering and Merck are German companies not related to the American drug giants Schering-Plough and Merck & Company.

articles.headline: Challenge for U.S.: Iraq's Handling of Detainees
articles.snippet: The blindfolded detainees in the dingy hallway line up in groups of five for their turn to see a judge, like schoolchildren outside the principal's office.      Each meeting lasts a few minutes. The judge rules whether the detainee will go free, f...
articles.abstract: The blindfolded detainees in the dingy hallway line up in groups of five for their turn to see a judge, like schoolchildren outside the principal's office.      Each meeting lasts a few minutes. The judge rules whether the detainee will go free, face trial or be held longer at this Iraqi base in northern Baghdad. But Firas Sabri Ali, squeezed into a fetid cell just hundreds of yards from the judge's office, has watched the inmates come and go for four months without his name ever being called.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMP JUSTICE, Iraq - The blindfolded detainees in the dingy hallway line up in groups of five for their turn to see a judge, like schoolchildren outside the principal's office.
